article.description: Freshman Amber Metoyer scored Colorado's last seven points, including a clinching basket with 1.5 seconds left, and the Buffaloes (No. 23 ESPN/USA Today, No. 24 AP) eked out a 64-63 win in a Big 12 opener Wednesday night.
article.headline: Buffs squeak past Cyclones in Big 12 opener
article.linkText: Metoyer's last-second shot lifts Colorado past Iowa State
article.story:
BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Iowa State shut down Colorado's top three scorers but had no answer for the Buffaloes' prolific bench.

Freshman Amber Metoyer scored Colorado's last seven points, including a clinching basket with 1.5 seconds left, and the Buffaloes (No. 23 ESPN/USA Today, No. 24 AP) eked out a 64-63 win in a Big 12 opener Wednesday night.

Colorado (11-1) trailed 56-45 with 8:13 remaining but outscored
Iowa State 19-7 the rest of the way to post its eighth straight
victory.

Metoyer had 11 of her 13 points during that stretch. Syreeta
Stafford and Randie Wirt each had 11 points for Colorado, which was
outshot 53 percent to 45 percent.

	   Lindsey Wilson scored 24 points for the Cyclones (5-7).

Metoyer and Veronica Johns-Richardson, both reserves, combined
to score Colorado's last 15 points.

The Buffaloes' bench outscored the Cyclone reserves 34-10,
helping compensate for the lack of scoring from starters Tera
Bjorklund, Kate Fagan and Sabrina Scott. That trio, which has
averaged a combined 44 points a game, was held to just 10.

"When people look at us, it looks like we have just three big
scorers,'' coach Ceal Barry said. "Tonight we showed we can score
in different ways. That's the mark of a good team. If they double
us, we need to find other ways to score.''

Barry said Metoyer, a 5-foot-10 forward, "lit the fire and it
was contagious. She was hot and wanted the ball tonight. We get the
ball to people who want it.''

Metoyer hit a short jumper in the lane and Johns-Richardson a 3-pointer as Colorado cut the deficit to 59-57.

Metoyer missed two free throws but Colorado got the rebound, and
Metoyer's 8-footer made it 59-59 with 2:38 left.

   After Metoyer made 1-of-2 free throws, Wilson hit a 15-foot jumper for a 61-60 lead with 1:38 left.

Metoyer's running hook in the lane made it 62-61. Wilson's two
free throws put the Cyclones ahead with 15.3 seconds to go, but
Metoyer muscled into the lane for the final basket, a short jumper.

   "Amber came through for us against Colorado State and
Syracuse,'' Barry said. "We decided to go to her at the end of the
game. (Linda) Lappe got the ball to her and she went up.''

Metoyer, who was averaging 4.4 points this season, said, "The
game was on the line, and coach told me to post up my player. I
just knew I had to score.

"When I'm in the zone, I'm in the zone. I knew I had the hot hand after the first basket I got in the second half (with 7:54 left).

"When you have your team behind you in big games like this and
they're counting on you, you've got to step up. That's what I
did.''

Iowa State center Lisa Kriener, who scored 21 points in the
Cyclones' last game, had only six points before fouling out with
2:51 left.

"Kriener had foul trouble early, and I think we struggled
without her,'' ISU coach Bill Fennelly said. "Metoyer had an
outstanding game. It was a great effort on her part.''

   Added Wilson, "We tried to stop their top three players. Give
Metoyer credit, she stepped up and played well. We weren't really
expecting it.''

In a game of surges and countersurges, Iowa State took a 32-30 halftime lead.

   Wilson scored 11 points in the first 7:22 of the second half,
including three 3-pointers.

The Cyclones fashioned an 8-0 run to open the half. After
Colorado countered with a 6-0 flurry, Iowa State scored eight
straight points, capped by Wilson's short jumper which beat the
shot clock, for a 50-38 lead.
